title: news.com.au — Australia’s #1 news site
text: Former Labor Leader Bill Shorten believes too many messages and a pledge to abolish franking credit refunds contributed to his defeat in the May election. In his first major interview since Labor's shock loss, Mr Shorten told the Herald Sun the proposals on tax reforms created a sense of vulnerability and anxiety among older Australians. The 52-year-old has taken full responsibility for the loss to Prime Minister Scott Morrison, and has ruled out returning to the Labor Leadership, but intends to stay in parliament and run for his seat of Maribyrong in the next election. Image: News Corp Australia
